title: Yvonne Reynders
text:
Yvonne Reynders (born 4 August 1937) is a former track and road <a href="cycle%20sport">cyclist</a> from <a href="Belgium">Belgium</a>. With <a href="Beryl%20Burton">Beryl Burton</a> of Great Britain, Reynders was one of the top female riders of the 1960s, winning 13 medals at world championships, including seven gold medals.
Reynders' first sport was <a href="Sport%20of%20athletics">athletics</a>: her heroine was Dutch athlete <a href="Fanny%20Blankers-Koen">Fanny Blankers-Koen</a>, who won four sprint golds at the <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a>. However, after her coaches told her that she did not have the speed on the track to follow in Blankers-Koen's footsteps, she initially switched to the discus, winning two consecutive Belgian junior discus titles in 1955 and 1956. Reynders then switched to cycle racing, having ridden a <a href="carrier%20tricycle">carrier tricycle</a> when delivering coal in <a href="Antwerp">Antwerp</a> after leaving school at the age of 16. In order to lose the muscle mass she had built up as a discus thrower, she developed a weekday routine of riding her race bike 40 km from her home in the <a href="Campine">Campine</a> to Antwerp, where she did her 8–16 km coal round on her carrier trike in the morning, and then riding another 100–140 km on her racing bicycle along the <a href="Scheldt">Scheldt</a> valley before returning home. After six months her weight had reduced from 74 kg to 59.5 kg. She subsequently won ten of the 14 races she entered in her first year, and earned selection to the Belgian national team.
Reynders won her first world road title in <a href="1959%20UCI%20Road%20World%20Championships">1959</a>. In <a href="1961%20UCI%20Road%20World%20Championships">1961</a> she won her second, defeating Burton and <a href="Elsy%20Jacobs">Elsy Jacobs</a>, and also won the world individual pursuit title <a href="1961%20UCI%20Track%20Cycling%20World%20Championships">the same year</a>. She won two more road world titles, in <a href="1963%20UCI%20Road%20World%20Championships">1963</a> on home ground in the Belgian city of <a href="Ronse">Ronse</a>, and in <a href="1966%20UCI%20Road%20World%20Championships">1966</a> at the <a href="N%C3%BCrburgring">Nürburgring</a> in <a href="West%20Germany">West Germany</a>, and another two track rainbow jerseys, in <a href="1964%20UCI%20Track%20Cycling%20World%20Championships">1964</a> and <a href="1965%20UCI%20Track%20Cycling%20World%20Championships">1965</a>. She initially retired from competition in 1967, however she returned to racing in 1976 at the age of 39: she took her final world championship medal, a bronze, at that year's <a href="1976%20UCI%20Road%20World%20Championships">Road World Championships</a>. She retired a second time the following year.
Reynders is a <a href="pedicure">pedicure</a> specialist.
